abstract.text: Encode a compute pass that runs computations in parallel on a thread grid, processing and manipulating Metal resource data on multiple cores of a GPU.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Your app can perform large-scale computation or prepare data for a subsequent GPU pass by encoding a compute pass that works on Metal resources in parallel. Compute passes are the part of your Metal pipeline meant for heavy parallelization of tasks requiring fast math, such as ray tracing.
Encode commands for your compute pass by creating a
and using it to create a new compute command encoder, using a method like
or

. Add individual dispatches for functions and their data to the compute pass by calling the command encoder’s methods. At the end of assigning data and dispatching a function call to the encoder, create a command that runs in your compute pass with
Everything used to set up your compute pass is CPU thread-safe, except for
. Synchronize
instances you share between the CPU and GPU with an
, an
, or a completion callback.
For information on dispatching commands to encode, see the
reference. Compute passes also support indirect command buffers; for more information, see Dispatching from Indirect Command Buffers.
The following two samples demonstrate basic compute passes:
See
for an example of configuring and running a compute pass that performs basic parallel math.
See
for an example of using a compute pass to modify data for a render pass.
Compute commands that execute your code on GPU call
kernel functions
in your Metal shader, annotated with
. Each kernel has associated argument tables, such as the buffer argument table

, used to access data associated with kernel arguments. In addition to annotations describing any argument table, some kernel arguments need information on their address space. For more information, see the following sections of the
For compute kernels, Section 5.1.3
For function argument tables, Section 5.2
For address spaces, Section 4

In addition, kernels also use a function table to take advantage of function pointers, allowing them to call visible and intersection functions. Visible functions allow you to use function pointers in kernels, letting you use function stitching and link against Metal dynamic libraries at runtime. Ray tracers use intersection functions on
instances to perform quick intersection checks.
For more information on function stitching, dynamic libraries, and ray tracing, see:
For information on per-architecture support for function tables in compute passes and other restrictions, see the
Compute kernels can access argument data to populate a Metal structure, using an
created by an
. For an in-depth discussion of argument buffers, see
. Using a resource in an argument buffer requires that it’s resident in GPU memory for the duration of the pass. For a resource to be resident, allocate it with either the
or
mode.
Resources become resident on a per-instance basis by calling methods like
and heaps become resident by calling methods like
For the duration of your compute pass, don’t access any resident resources on the CPU. Doing so in your app can cause GPU memory corruption, such as visual artifacts.
When using resident resources, avoid data corruption by using an appropriate
or by manually managing memory barriers and fences for untracked resources with the methods in Synchronizing Across Command Execution.

content.text: Using Tile Memory in a Compute Pass

inlineContent.text: Apple family GPUs offer fast, integrated graphics memory called
tile memory

that’s shared between subsequent passes for fast access to data. Compute passes can reserve this memory space for threadgroup memory or imageblock memory, giving your compute functions the ability to access temporary data at low latency across your shaders.
For more information see the following sections of the
Section 4.4 for information on the
memory space
Section 4.5 for information on the
memory space
Section 2.11 for information on imageblocks
Section 5.6 for information on
attributes

Because tile memory resides on GPU only, you reserve memory on a tile block rather than copy data to it. Use the methods in Encoding Tile Memory Usage to prepare the appropriate block of memory for your kernel.
For device support and other tile memory limitations, see

abstract.text: Render advanced 3D graphics and compute data in parallel with graphics processors.
A collection of model data for GPU-accelerated intersection of rays with the model.
An object used to encode data into an argument buffer.
A resource that stores data in a format defined by your app.
A container that stores a sequence of GPU commands that you encode into it.
Creates a compute command encoder that uses default settings.
Creates a compute command encoder from a descriptor.
Declares that all command generation from the encoder is completed.
An interface for dispatching commands to encode in a compute pass.
Ensures the shaders in the render pass’s subsequent draw commands have access to all of the resources you allocate from a heap.
Ensures kernel calls that the system encodes in subsequent commands have access to a resource.
A description of how to dispatch execution of pass commands and GPU performance sampling.
A configuration that instructs the GPU where to store counter data from the beginning and end of a compute pass.
A container that stores an array of sample buffer attachments for a compute pass.
An instance describing the desired GPU state for a kernel call in a compute pass.
An interface that represents a GPU pipeline configuration for running kernels in a compute pass.
The data layout required for arguments needed to specify the size of threadgroups.
The type of dispatch method to use when calling encoded functions.
A simple semaphore to synchronize access to Metal resources.
A memory fence to capture, track, and manage resource dependencies across command encoders.
The options you use to specify the hazard tracking mode.
The mutability options for a buffer that a render or compute pipeline uses.
An array of pipeline buffer descriptors.
Options that determine how Metal prepares the pipeline.
An allocation of memory accessible to a GPU.
A description of the input and output data of a function.
The CPU and GPU may maintain separate copies of the resource, and any changes must be explicitly synchronized.
The CPU and GPU share access to the resource, allocated in system memory.
Encode a block information transfer pass to adjust and copy data to and from GPU resources, such as buffers and textures.
Calculate the optimum sizes for threadgroups and grids when dispatching compute-processing workloads.
Compile a library of shaders and write it to a file as a dynamically linked library.
Learn how Metal organizes compute-processing workloads.
Define custom shader behavior at runtime by creating functions from existing ones and preferentially linking to others in a dynamic library.
